it really easy for them to move around and take their work with them anywhere
they go. Which also really suits their location independent or nomadic
lifestyle. Now.. conversely a digital nomad is NOT somebody who would ever risk
their livelihood-making-machine also known as "their laptop" to sun and sand
and salt water and all of the things by just taking crazy photos on the beach and
other locations. Actually, I'm really really guilty of having done this when I

the first time in history where it's more achievable than ever before for you
to actually make a really great in profitable career from your laptop while
traveling the world. So if you're someone who's been dreaming of quitting their

skills or passions you already possess that you can bring into an online career.
Now you might be surprised to know that a lot of your existing skills can really
easily be translated into an online career but
that's not really the point. The point isn't just to have an online career and
be able to make money online. It's to create a profitable and sustainable
online career that's going to allow you to have the freedom you want in your
life. There's gonna be lots of different YouTube videos and tutorials and blog
posts all about how you can make money with no skills at all. So of course you
can get paid for things like reviewing Amazon books and even hotels and
restaurants and taking surveys. But that is not what's going to create this kind
of sustainable lifestyle for you when it comes to earning money online and
growing your business. Trust me when I say that the more you put into it the
more you'll get out of it. Make sure to check out my video that's all about how
to find that sweet spot where your passions and your purpose and your
skills all overlap and how to build this into your digital nomad skill set and
where to kind of focus your efforts. But the truth is the most in-demand and the
highest paid skills online are going to take the longest to learn. Which is
natural with absolutely anything out there that's worth doing so the key is
just to start little by little. When I first started working online I started
posting on Instagram for my clients for $20 an hour just creating really simple
graphics and managing their social accounts. And then over the years I
started building onto that skill set to also be able to design websites and
build out really complex marketing funnels that's allowing me to charge a
lot more than $20 an hour. But the key is just to start and then also reinvest
into your learning as you go. So Step 2 then is gonna be to actually build out
your skills. Now you can actually do this using free resources out there like
YouTube videos pretty much these days and some blog posts. But I don't recommend
it cause when you're first starting out you need someone who's an expert in that
field to help structure the content for you so you're not overwhelming yourself
by jumping into the more complex stuff first. When you're looking for online
courses you can go to websites like LinkedIn Learning which used to be
Lynda.com that are taught by more professional instructors that are
certified in their field of expertise... or you can go to online marketplaces like
Udemy or Skillshare which are taught by regular people just like me
which are a little bit more digestible and I find them to be a little bit more
human and engaging. But make sure to check out what their reviews are like
and what other students are saying before jumping into a course now on
udemy you can get a course anywhere from about 10 to 20 dollars when they're all
on sale and on Skillshare at the time of recording it's about twenty dollars for
a monthly subscription that gives you access to all of their amazing courses.
So I really recommend these two methods and then also supplementing that with
free online learning like using YouTube for that. You can, of course, also take
some more expensive, more advanced courses that are about five hundred to
five thousand dollars... but when you're first starting out my biggest piece of
advice is to not overwhelm yourself by investing way too much into this journey
before you really know if you're enjoying it before you even know if it's
something that you really want. So start with the more kind of budget conscious
choices and then continue reinvesting into your learning. Now for those of you
out there who are gonna say "oh don't I actually need a formal degree to work in
this field?" whatever your chosen field is, I'm gonna tell you right now that I
don't have a formal qualification in digital marketing. I taught myself
everything I know and I have worked with everyone from solopreneurs to
multi-million dollar enterprises and digital marketing agencies and just
about everyone in between and not once has anybody asked me for a formal
qualification proof. Because I know what I'm doing and that's so much more
important in the online world than a piece of paper. And also a three or four
year Bachelor's Degree or any other kind of degree is gonna be so outdated by the
time you would graduate that there's really no point. Because the digital
world is just moving far too quickly. Alright so now I'm moving on to Step 3 -
which is to build out your portfolio. Now once again this does not have to be this
complex custom coded expensive WordPress site like a lot of people would suggest
that you need. You can easily do this by just pimping out your LinkedIn profile
or if you're maybe working full time still and you don't want your boss
getting suspicious about your sudden career change on your LinkedIn profile..
then just go ahead and build a one-page portfolio sign with a free
tool like Strikingly. If you'd like to learn how to do that make sure to check
out my video on how to build your one page portfolio site in less than 30
minutes. Again when I first started I had no way to do this either and I was
actually still working full-time so I couldn't do anything with my LinkedIn
profile all I did is put together some graphics on Canva, I put together a few
marketing videos and I also did a few articles on Medium.com which is a free
site where I could showcase my copywriting style and then I linked
everything to my one page portfolio site that I could then send when I was
reaching out to clients on LinkedIn or through Facebook groups. So it can be
something really simple like that, it doesn't have to be really complicated
and I promise you it's a lot more than a lot of other freelancers out there doing.
So Step 4 then is to decide on your business model. Now... the digital nomad
work pool kind of divides itself into these three categories: one is working
remotely, the second one is freelancing on a contract basis, and the last one is
running your own online business. So let's talk about some pros and cons of
each of these to decide which one might be right for you.
Alright so now starting with working remotely. An example might be if you were
a full-time social media manager for an e-commerce brand - this can mean taking
your existing job that you already have remote by negotiating with your boss or
maybe applying for a full-time permanent remote role on sites like RemoteOK or
We Work Remotely. Pros of this is that you can work full time get benefits even
a holiday and sick pay just working from your laptop and you have a consistent
rate of pay month-to-month. Cons are that you are likely restricted to the
timezone of your employer so you can't just pick up and move halfway across the
world because you might be stuck working from 9:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m. instead and
driving yourself a little bit nuts. When it comes to freelancing - examples of this
would be a copywriter for a health food brand, a video editor for a yoga youtube
channel, or a graphic designer for an accounting firm. These types of jobs you
can get through networking either in person or online
in Facebook groups or LinkedIn outreach or dedicated platforms
like Freelancer and Upwork. The pros of this is that you have flexibility of
clients and flexibility in the type of work you do and your contract length. If,
like me, you really enjoy dynamic work - then this might be the way to go for you..
because it will allow you to work on multiple projects with multiple clients
and also generally allow you to charge higher rates as you're not on a salary
but you're on an hourly weekly or per project payment structure. Now the cons
of this is that it can be an organisational nightmare if you're not
naturally organised, and you also have to be really good at setting boundaries
with your clients because you might have five or more clients at a time. And your
pay might also vary from month to month. So those are some things to consider
there. Now the last of these is starting your own online business for things like
Dropshipping or Amazon FBA or online course creation or having other digital
products like a membership site for example. Now the pros here is that it can
be much more passive once you get a little bit of momentum especially when
it comes to digital products like online courses where you can create your course
once and then sites like Udemy or Skillshare will actually sell it for you
and market it for you. Now the cons here are that this is the riskiest of the
three strategies and it's very hands-on and time-consuming especially when
you're setting everything up. So it does kind of seem that everyone in the online
world is always telling you to niche down and narrow down and find your niche. And
I would actually disagree with this and go out on a limb here a little bit.
Because it wasn't really my approach and it isn't to this day. When I first
started working online, and for quite a while afterwards... I focused on just
getting as many experiences in as many fields as I could. So I made an effort to
work with clients of all different sizes all different customer bases and in
different industries so I could learn what worked for me and what didn't and
where my passions really were. So I worked with everyone from baby clothing
brands and investors and software developers and
energy retailers and everyone in between. So I could figure out what I actually
really wanted to focus on in the future. So I would recommend that before even
thinking about starting your own online business and your own passive income
which is the goal, and it's exactly what I ended up doing with my online courses
to supplement my freelancing income - I would try and get as many experiences
working with a variety of clients before deciding on what's right for you. And now

Moving on to Step 5... before we go into how to decide where to actually set up
your virtual office in Step 6 I also wanted to cover something that people
seem to forget about a lot when it comes to this Digital Nomad lifestyle which is
all about knowing your numbers. What I mean by this is just you need to know
what your expenses are every month so you need to know exactly what you need
to earn in order to just break even and then also to earn more on top to
contribute to your savings. So if you know that 2k a month is the bare
minimum you need to make in order to break even on your expenses, and you're
charging $50 an hour then you know that 40 hours that month is the minimum you
need to work in order to break even. Assuming you're also charging your taxes
in your country on top of your hourly rate. So it really scares me when people
don't really know their revenue and profit numbers. If they say things like
I'm making a hundred grand a month from Facebook Ads!

be really conscious of being able to put money aside for doing really exciting
things in the place that you're in! There's no point in living in beautiful
places like Cambodia and Bali if you're not putting a little bit of money aside
on doing really exciting things in the place that you're in and exploring
nature, and culture and all those wonderful things that come along with
being able to be a digital nomad. So now at Step 6 -
let's talk about how to actually choose your
ideal travel destination. First and foremost - be VERY aware of time zones. So
at the moment I'm in Australia and if I had an Aussie client and I was gonna go
back home to visit my family in Canada for a couple of months that might mean a
few 3 a.m. Skype calls with my clients. Which might be fine from time to time
but probably not sustainable long term. So be very aware of time zones first and
foremost and then really think about things like cost of living, internet
speed, temperature, culture, food... all of the things that really matter to you.
That are individual to where you want to travel to. My favourite resource for this
is Nomadlist - it has a rating for every digital nomad hotspot around the
world. Including average cost of living per month, temperature, Wi-Fi speed and it
even has a fun and safety rating. And this awesome website even connects other
digital nomads in a helpful community forum and even has a dating section!
which brings me to my next and final point
Step 7 - connect with your people! I cannot say this enough but co-working spaces
might just be the best investment that you make as a digital nomad. Some of my
favourite people I've met from around the world have been through co-working
spaces especially when I was living in Canggu, Bali. So these kind of
co-working spaces will put a lot of effort into connecting their community
and having skill share sessions so people can pass on their knowledge to others.
And you might find people who are in your industry and in your niche and in
your skill set who are just those few steps ahead, who can help you out. And likewise
you will find people who are a few steps behind where you are which will allow
